metadata.notes: Second Sunday of Easter, 1994. Context includes contemporary media skepticism (Jesus Seminar) and local tragedies (Alabama tornado).

freedom_from_critical_parent_CP.score_explanation: 10 = Completely free from coercive judgments. 0 = Very dominant Critical Parent.
freedom_from_critical_parent_CP.analysis: The CP manifests as an intellectual gatekeeper. The preacher uses judgmental language ('trendy disaffections', 'atheistic clergy') to categorize opposing views as illegitimate, effectively shaming the 'skeptical' parts of the listener's mind.
quotes: the Jesus Seminar is no help whatsoever
I choose to go along with Raymond Brown

healthy_care_NP.score_explanation: 10 = Healthy, non-smothering care. 0 = Absent or smothering.
healthy_care_NP.analysis: The Nurturing Parent is strong, offering comfort in the face of death and tragedy. However, it leans toward dependency by suggesting that only the 'Word' (as interpreted by the preacher) can provide the necessary strength to survive grief.
quotes: It is a very comforting thing to me... to know that the relationship of doubt to faith is built into the Easter story.
God has entered our pain and been wounded by it.

adult.analysis: The preacher engages in data processing by citing scholars and news reports. However, the Adult is often bypassed by an appeal to 'revelation' which shuts down the Adult's 'testing against reality' in favor of a Parent-sanctioned 'Word'.
quotes: His intent in doing so is not only scholarly but also pastoral...
We have a real choice. We can choose a god who suits us... or the Bible sets before us a baffling, even an infuriating God.

freedom_from_adapted_child_AC.score_explanation: 10 = Free from fear/compliance. 0 = Strong Adapted Child (fear culture).
freedom_from_adapted_child_AC.analysis: The preacher models the Adapted Child by describing her own 'struggles' and 'buffeting' by skeptical articles, then 'complying' with the Word to find relief. This invites the congregation to likewise suppress their own 'treacherous' inner voices.
quotes: I did not like the feeling of doubt that I was experiencing.
My 'inner voice' was saying all sorts of treacherous things.

free_child_FC.analysis: There is very little spontaneity or joy. The tone is heavy, focused on death, wounds, and the 'futility' of faith if certain dogmas aren't true.
quotes: I am amused to think how different this is...
shout at him, to ask repeatedly the ultimate question, 'Why?'

transaction_analysis.analysis: The preacher positions herself as a fellow sufferer (Child) who finds the answer in the 'Word' (Parent), then turns to the congregation as a Nurturing Parent to offer that same 'Word'. It creates a dependency loop where the listener's Adult is discouraged from independent validation.
transaction_analysis.ulterior_motives: Social: A->A (Discussing theology/news). Psychological: P->C ('Your own thoughts are treacherous; listen only to the external Word I am providing').
transaction_analysis.risk_explanation: The 'double bottom' lies in the vulnerability. By sharing her own doubt, she gains the listener's trust (Con), only to then label that same doubt as 'treacherous' and 'futile' (Switch).

detected_games.name: Bait & Switch / Redemption

formula_g_analysis.con: Validation of the listener's doubt ('Thomas stands for all of us').
formula_g_analysis.gimmick: The listener's fear of death and meaninglessness ('If Christ has not been raised, your faith is futile').
formula_g_analysis.switch: Moving from 'doubt is okay' to 'doubt is a treacherous inner voice' that must be silenced by the 'Word from outside'.
formula_g_analysis.payoff: Relief through submission to the external authority; the preacher feels 'restored' and the congregation feels 'safe' but dependent.

evidence_quotes: It is a very comforting thing... to know that the relationship of doubt to faith is built into the Easter story.
My 'inner voice' was saying all sorts of treacherous things... In that reading from the Word of God my faith was restored.

detected_games.name: Ain't It Awful

formula_g_analysis.con: Shared concern over the state of the world/church.
formula_g_analysis.gimmick: The desire for an 'us vs. them' identity.
formula_g_analysis.switch: Lumping scholars and New Agers into a group that 'delights in showing the NT is not true'.
formula_g_analysis.payoff: A sense of superior 'hard-core' faithfulness compared to the 'trendy' outsiders.

evidence_quotes: I cannot remember a time... when Christian faith was under direct attack as much as it is today.
The trendy disaffections of the Jesus Seminar... are of little interest.

preacher_roles.rescuer: High. The preacher offers the 'Word' as the only shield against the 'treacherous' inner voice and the 'futility' of life.
preacher_roles.persecutor: Low-Medium. Directed at the 'Jesus Seminar' and 'New Age' thinkers who are portrayed as deceptive or foolish.
preacher_roles.victim: Medium. The preacher presents herself as 'buffeted' by skepticism and grieving multiple deaths, inviting the congregation to join her in this vulnerable state.

drama_triangle_analysis.congregation_position: Victim. The congregation is portrayed as being under 'attack' by the media and 'buffeted' by life's tragedies, needing the Rescuer's Word.
drama_triangle_analysis.escape_possibilities: Minimal. The sermon suggests that 'auto-enlightenment' (Adult autonomy) is equivalent to making up a god. The only way out is submission to the 'Voice from outside'.

conclusion_and_recommendation.summary: The sermon is a classic example of a 'Nurturing Parent' intervention that ultimately reinforces dependency. While it provides genuine emotional comfort regarding grief, it does so by pathologizing the listener's 'Adult' faculty of critical thinking (labeling it as a 'treacherous inner voice'). By creating a dichotomy between 'man-made' (bad/self) and 'revelation' (good/external), it discourages the development of an autonomous, integrated faith. The preacher uses her own vulnerability as a 'Con' to lead the listener into a 'Bait & Switch' where the only resolution for doubt is the total abandonment of the 'inner voice' in favor of the preacher's interpretation of the 'Word'.
strengths: High empathy for the grieving process.
Strong use of narrative to connect with the audience's 'Child' ego state.
Effective identification with the 'Victim' role to build rapport.
areas_for_improvement: De-escalate the 'Critical Parent' attacks on intellectual inquiry.
Validate the 'Adult' ego state as a God-given tool for discernment rather than a 'treacherous' enemy.
Reduce the 'Bait & Switch' dynamic regarding doubt.
conclusion_and_recommendation.advice_for_game_free_communication: Try to address the congregation as 'Adults' who can hold both doubt and faith simultaneously without needing one to 'silence' the other. Instead of positioning the 'Word' as an external force that overrides the 'inner voice,' explore how the 'Free Child' and 'Adult' can interact with the 'Word' to find authentic, non-coerced belief.
